intro: Salvia palaestina, commonly known as Palestinian sage, is a perennial herb native to the Middle East and parts of North Africa. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring opposite, lance-shaped leaves with a slightly hairy texture. Its flowers are usually violet to blue-purple, arranged in whorled clusters at the ends of the stems. Salvia palaestina is often found in rocky soils and dry habitats, making it well adapted to arid environments.
